awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Band Engineering in Amorphous Semiconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: At the core of today?s electronics are semiconductor materials. The optical energy at which a semiconductor strongly absorbs light is known as its bandgap. By mixing two different materials to form a semiconductor alloy, its bandgap can be tuned. The first goal of this project is to study the fundamental materials properties and bandgap tuning in alloys made of amorphous, or disordered, oxide semiconductors. These wide bandgap materials are less explored but very promising for applications of strong societal importance such as devices for renewable energy and health care. The second goal of this project is to bring together research and education by engaging the entire research team in outreach activities with the public, including school-age learners. In addition, the principal investigator provides mentoring to graduate and undergraduate students through research activities and ?Career Connections? events featuring discussions with practicing scientists and engineers.

Technical Description: This project explores band engineering of amorphous oxide semiconductor thin films via quaternary and quinary alloying. These materials have a wide bandgap, similar to that of gallium nitride. Multi-component phase diagrams are used to relate oxide alloy composition to thermodynamic stability and materials properties. The specific objectives of this project are: (i) to investigate the alloy composition ranges and thermodynamic pathways available for meta-stable band-engineered amorphous alloy films; (ii) to characterize charge transport and sub-bandgap density of states as a function of alloy composition, using electrical and opto-electronic techniques; (iii) to develop models and experimentally validate hetero-structure interface formation in amorphous oxide alloys. Through these studies, this project significantly expands the present scientific understanding and application scope of disordered semiconductors. Heterostructures made using these band-engineered amorphous oxide alloys can be used in future high-power electronics or deep ultraviolet optoelectronics devices.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the development of synthesis processes and characterization of wide and ultra-wide bandgap oxide semiconductors with tunable energy bands. Band-engineering is a critical technology for diverse electronic and optical devices. By creating adjacent layers with different energy band positions, charge carriers can be confined, enabling devices such as high electron mobility transistors and quantum well photodetectors.

In the first part of this project, we focused on the alloying of zinc tin oxide amorphous oxide semiconductor with magnesium to achieve band engineering. We chose zinc tin oxide due to its earth abundant composition. We developed a solution-based deposition method for magnesium alloyed zinc tin oxide and investigated the properties of the material as a function of magnesium concentration. Using in situ heating x-ray diffraction measurements, we found that the magnesium concentration modified the crystallization pathways and crystallization temperature of the thin film. By adjusting the magnesium content from 0 to 20%, the zinc tin oxide film can be tuned to predominantly crystalize in either the orthorhombic or inverse spinel structure. The maximum crystallization temperature is found for intermediate magnesium concentrations between 5 and 10%.

We experimentally investigated the diffusion of magnesium in zinc tin oxide heterostructures, and found that it was critical to perform an anneal after deposition of each layer within the structure in order to minimize the total amount of interdiffusion. We built a model of magnesium diffusion and fit the model, including diffusion constants, to our experimental results. We also characterized the electrical properties of the films as a function of magnesium incorporation. We found that magnesium alloying slightly degrades thin film transistor behavior, possibly due to changes in oxygen bonding at the gate insulator interface and back-channel free surface. In characterizing the films’ optical properties, we were unable to obtain a significant change in optical bandgap after magnesium alloying. We attribute the lack of bandgap widening to the band edge disorder present in the alloyed material. Because of the difficulty in obtaining band edge engineering, we then turned our energy to a second technical thrust.

In the second part of this project, we focused on the use of aerosol-based pyrolysis chemical vapor deposition, so-called mist-CVD, to deposit oxide semiconductors. We successfully built a mist-CVD tool and developed a baseline process for deposition of an ultra-wide bandgap semiconductor, gallium oxide (Ga2O3). We showed successful epitaxial deposition of kappa-phase gallium oxide on c-plane sapphire. The epitaxial growth of kappa-phase (κ-)Ga2O3, an ultra-wide bandgap semiconductor with a bandgap of 4.9-5 eV and large spontaneous polarization along the c-axis, opens up new possibilities for ferroelectric devices, high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs) that rely on two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) formation, and quantum well infrared photodetectors built using superlattice heterostructures of κ-Ga2O3 and Al-alloyed κ-Ga2O3.

The synthesis techniques used here are relevant to a variety of scientifically-compelling materials including wide and ultra-wide bandgap (UWBG) oxide semiconductors such as gallium oxide, aluminum or indium-alloyed gallium oxide, zinc gallate, magnesium gallate, and others. UWBG materials are of particular interest for energy efficient high voltage power electronics, ultraviolet (solar-blind) photodetection, as well as high temperature/extreme-environment sensors and electronics.

Throughout the project, undergraduate researchers have participated in the project. In particular, several undergraduate students contributed to the development of a transient photoconductivity and illuminated Hall tool that can characterize semiconductor properties on time scales of tens of hours, as a function of applied temperature, providing novel research capability for studying sub-bandgap semiconductor defect states with slow emission time constants. In addition, a Career Connections program was launched in the undergraduate classes taught by the PI. Finally, dissemination of results has occurred via conference presentations, and will continue via future archival journal publications.
